intro: Asclepias engelmanniana var. rusbyi, commonly known as the Rusby's milkweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and pairs of opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of pale yellow to greenish-white flowers with distinctive, hood-like structures. It is a member of the Apocynaceae family and is known for its milky sap, which is a characteristic feature of the genus Asclepias. This species plays an important role in supporting monarch butterfly populations by providing nectar and a host plant for their larvae.
